group.label: E0 Complete these facility specific questions before continuing.

input.label: E0:01a What type of cold chain equipment is used in the store?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Answers to this question switch later indicators on and off.

select1.label: A. Vaccine is stored in cold room(s) and/or freezer room(s)
B. Vaccine is stored in refrigerators or long-term cold boxes
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Including solar refrigerators. 'Long-term cold box' means a device that can reliably store vaccine for over 7 days without power (PQS specification in preparation).

select1.label: C. Vaccine is stored in freezers
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Including solar freezers.

select1.label: D. Coolant-packs, including ice-packs and/or cool-packs and/or PCM-packs are prepared in the store
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Select 'Y' if there is equipment in the store used exclusively for preparing coolant-packs (ice-packs and/or cool-packs and/or PCM-packs). Ignore fridge/freezers with ice-pack compartments or freezer rooms/cold rooms that are also used to store vaccine.

input.label: Notes:
E0:02a Where are vaccines and diluents, syringes and safety boxes stored?
input.hint: Guidance Notes : It is common for syringes and safety boxes to be stored in separate buildings either in the vaccine store compound, or elsewhere - these sites and buildings need to be checked.

select1.label: A. Only vaccines are stored. The facility is not responsible for syringes and safety boxes?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Syringes and safety boxes may enter the immunization supply chain at a lower level than the primary store if they are received direct from the manufacturer or from another government department or agency. These products will always be stored at lowest delivery and health facility levels.

select1.label: B. Vaccine storage and dry storage in the same building?
C. Vaccine storage and dry storage in separate buildings on the same site?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Answer "Y" if all or some of the dry goods are stored in separate buildings on the same site.

select1.label: D. Vaccine storage and dry storage on separate sites?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Answer "Y" if all or some of the dry goods are stored on separate sites.

input.label: E0:02a Notes:
E0:03a What type of equipment is used to deliver and/or collect vaccine at this store?

select1.label: A. Cold boxes, vaccine carriers and/or other passive containers?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Other passive containers' includes insulated roll containers or palletized containers. These may be used at primary and sub-national levels.

select1.label: B. Refrigerated vehicles?

input.label: Notes:
E0:04a How are vaccine transport operations organized at this store? [Select at least one option, but not B without A]:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Enter all options that apply. 'Transport' includes bicycles, motorcycles, cars, trucks, boats and aircraft. If the vehicle(s) are shared between programmes, choose the option which best describes the sharing arrangement - for example: 'government agency' - and record arrangement in Notes.

select1.label: A. Vaccine transport is operated by the government, a parastatal agency, or is directly operated by the store.
B. Vaccine transport is operated by a PPP or 3PL.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: PPP = public-private partnership. 3PL= third party logistics contractor.

select1.label: C. This store does not organize any official transport. Either the store does not organize any transport, or informal arrangements (public transport, taxi, private vehicle, ) are made for vaccine transport.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: "Official" transport is one or both of A and B. It does not include buses, taxis, private vehicles or other informal arrangements.

input.label: Notes:
E0:05a Specify all transport types used for vaccine delivery or collection at this level.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: List all transport types: government-operated, parastatal or private.

select1.label: A. On foot
B. Bicycles and/or motorcycles
C. Cars, vans, trucks, refrigerated trucks and other road vehicles
D. Aircraft
E. Railway
F. Boat
G. Other

input.label: Notes:

group.label: E1 - Pre-shipment and arrival procedures ensure that every shipment from the vaccine manufacturer reaches the receiving store in satisfactory condition and with correct paperwork.

input.label: E1:01a How are vaccines supplied to this primary store?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Answer all sub-questions. There can be more than one answer = 'Y'. If vaccine is received direct from the manufacturer at more than one store, each of these stores should be assessed as a primary store.

select1.label: A. Via a UN source (e.g. UNICEF-SD or PAHO)
B. From an inter-country distribution warehouse
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Inter-country distribution warehouses serve a group of countries. They may hold routine vaccines or strategic stocks of epidemic vaccines.

select1.label: C. Direct from international manufacturer(s)
D. Transfers or donations from a neighbouring country or state
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Transfers or donations from a neighbouring country or state' covers the situation where a country in the region, or a separate state within a large country, has excess vaccine with a short expiry date. To avoid unnecessary wastage this may be transferred to another country or state for a supplementary immunization activity or even for routine use.

select1.label: E. Direct from in-country manufacturer(s)

input.label: Notes:
E1:02b Does the local Vaccine Arrival Report (VAR) form include all the key procedures from UNICEF VAR Parts I to VII?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: For international suppliers see UNICEF VAR guidance note (hyperlink below). For in-country manufacturers, the layout of the VAR should reflect local delivery arrangements, but should retain the key checking procedures on the UNICEF VAR. See also EVM Model SOP: EVM-SOP-E1-02: Vaccine arrival procedures.

select1.label: A. VAR Part I - Advance notice section
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: http://www.thephss.org/ppep/resource/VAR_English_2010.pdf

select1.label: B. VAR Part II - Flight arrival details
C. VAR Part III - Shipment details
D. VAR Part IV - Documentation checklist
E. VAR Part V - Shipping indicator status
F. VAR Part VI - General condition of shipment
G. VAR Part VII - Inspection supervisor signature

input.label: Notes:
E1:03b Assess vaccine arrival reports (VARs) received during the review period:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Due to differences between vaccines in temperature sensitivity and packaging, only one type of vaccine should be recorded on each VAR. Therefore in the case of combined deliveries, a separate VAR should be completed for each vaccine in the shipment. For deliveries of DTP-HepB+Hib, one VAR should be used for DTP-HepB and another VAR for the lyophilized Hib, again due to differences in temperature sensitivity and packaging.

input.label: A. How many individual vaccine arrivals have there been?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Diluent and droppers must be detailed on the same VAR as the vaccines with which they have been shipped.

input.label: B. There should be a VAR accompanying each individual vaccine. Record the number of VARs that were actually received.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: In the event of short shipment (quantity received does not match quantity on packing list) of vaccine, diluents or droppers, where the quantity that was short-shipped is delivered at a later date, separate VARs must be completed for each delivery.

input.label: C. Record how many of these received VARs were completed correctly by the 'Inspection Supervisor', including a complete and correct record of the status of electronic temperature monitoring devices.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Inspection Supervisor' is the term used in the UNICEF VAR. 'Completed correctly' means that the UNICEF VAR Part III to Part VII, or local equivalent, must have been completed in full. This includes correct and complete reporting of the status of electronic temperature monitoring devices. The VAR and related documents (e.g. pre-shipment advice, lot release, etc.) should be filed together.

input.label: D. Record how many of the vaccine arrivals were delayed for more than 6 hours at customs due to lack of storage space in the primary store, or lack of transport.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: UNICEF-SD indicate that lack of storage space or transport at primary store level can cause last minute customs clearance delays. This is usually the result of poor planning by the country.

input.label: E1:03b Notes:
E1:04a Of the individual vaccine arrivals entered in E1:03b:A:
A. How many were received in exposed or damaged condition?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Exposed or damaged condition' in this context means that the accompanying shipping indicators showed evidence of exposure to excessive heat or cold (UNICEF VAR Part V), and/or that the shipment was physically damaged (UNICEF VAR Part VI).

input.label: B. How many of these exposed or damaged arrivals were correctly followed up with the supplier within three days of receipt?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Correctly followed up' means that the supplier (UNICEF-SD or vaccine manufacturer as appropriate) was formally contacted and that arrangements were made to test or replace the vaccine. If all shipments were satisfactory, question B is automatically switched off.

input.label: E1:04a Notes:
E1:05a Of the individual vaccine arrivals entered in E1:03b.A:
A. How many VARs reported incomplete accompanying documentation?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Accompanying documentation' in this context must include the following: Airway Bill (or Waybill for local suppliers), Packing List, Invoice and Lot Release Certificate from the NRA in the country of origin (UNICEF VAR Part IV). Omission of any of these items indicates that the paperwork is incomplete.

input.label: B. How many of these incompletely documented arrivals were followed up within 14 days of receipt?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Followed up' means that the supplier was formally contacted and that the missing paperwork was supplied.

input.label: E1:05a Notes:
E1:06b If any vaccines come from an international source. Assess international lot release procedures during the review period.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Lot release procedures: 1. The quality of the vaccines must be assured by the National Regulatory Authority (NRA) of the country producing the vaccine (NRA). This NRA must license the product and release it on a lot by lot basis. In addition, the NRA must ensure on-going regulatory oversight through regular inspections of Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) and monitoring of Adverse Events Following Immunization (AEFIs). 2. The NRA provides a lot release certificate for each batch following detailed review of the documentation from the manufacturer (about raw materials used, GMP inspection, test protocols and results for that particular batch), which may or may not be supported by testing. 3. A procuring country with or without a fully-functioning NRA of its own can rely on the lot release certificate provided by the NRA of the producing country. If a country procures vaccines through the UN, the country may waive the lot release as the pre-qualification process already relies on the lot release certificate of the producing country. However, a procuring country with a fully functioning NRA may still choose to carry out its own lot release procedure.

input.label: A. How many individual vaccine lots were received during the review period?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: 4. There are cases where a vaccine that is not used in the producing country, will not be licensed in that country. This situation is covered by a Scientific Opinion under Article 58 of the current legislation in Europe - a procedure developed in collaboration with WHO. The Scientific Opinion is given by the European Medicines Agency (EMEA) and the procedure is equivalent to that performed for products licensed for use in the European Community. However, since the product will not be placed in the European market, they cannot issue a Marketing Authorization. EMEA will also evaluate lots and issue an equivalent to a Certificate of Batch Release. A procuring country can use a positive Scientific Opinion to license the vaccine through its own NRA. See: http://www.who.int/immunization_standards/vaccine_regulation/article_58_guidelines_0505.pdf

input.label: B. For every lot received there should be a lot release certificate from the NRA in the country of origin, or an EMEA lot evaluation. Record the number actually received.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: 5. If the procuring country does not have an NRA, or if its NRA is not competent enough to analyze licensing dossiers, it can use the expertise of a fully functional NRA in another country to carry out the protocol review and testing process on its behalf, or to check whether the vaccine has a positive Certificate of Batch Release.

select1.label: C. Does the country issue its own lot release certificates?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: 6. WHO recommends that each country carry out lot release and issue lot release certificates, either through a fully-functional NRA or by using the expertise of a fully-functional NRA in another country. In such circumstances, there should be an MoU with the relevant NRA.

input.label: D. Answer ONLY if the country issues its own lot release certificates. For every lot received there should be such a lot release certificate. Record the number actually received.
E1:06b Notes:
E1:07a If any vaccines come from a local manufacturer. Assess local manufacturer lot release procedures used for the release of vaccine lots during the review period:
A. How many individual vaccine lots were received during the review period?
B. There should be a lot release certificate from the local NRA for every lot received. Record the number actually received.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: There should also be an MoU with the local NRA.

input.label: E1:07a Notes:
E1:08a If any vaccines have been donated or transferred from another country or state. Assess lot release certificates for donated and transferred vaccines during the review period.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Inter-country or inter-state donations and transfers should be treated just like any other vaccine arrival. Lot release certificates are required for quality assurance purposes.

input.label: A. How many individual donated or transferred vaccine lots were received during the review period?
B. There should be a lot release certificate for every lot received. Record the number actually received.
E1:08a Notes:
E1:09a If any vaccines come from an international source. Checklist for working arrangements with customs and/or the NRA.

select1.label: A. Do working arrangements with customs and/or NRA ensure protection of the cold chain?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Customs/NRA staff must understand the importance of the cold chain and must maintain clear channels of communication with staff at the primary vaccine store.

select1.label: B. Is there an SOP or MoU document which specifies working procedures with customs and/or the NRA?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: An SOP is the best way to detail the responsibilities of the parties. There may also be a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU). However, an MoU is of no operational significance unless it describes the responsibilities of the parties.

select1.label: C. Do the procedures set out in the SOP or MoU define the responsibilities of the parties, response times and cold chain procedures?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: As a minimum, the SOP or MoU must set out the responsibilities of the parties, monitoring procedures and agreed response times and must define cold chain procedures. Wherever possible, vaccine should be moved from the port of entry to the primary vaccine store within 24 hours of arrival.

select1.label: D. Is there documentary evidence to show that agreed procedures are followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: The best evidence will be obtained from the electronic shipping indicators. If these are downloaded AFTER the vaccine arrives in the primary store, the history will show if there have been temperature excursions whilst the vaccine is held by customs.

input.label: E1:09a Notes:

select1.label: E1:10a If any vaccines come from an international source, requiring customs clearance. Have customs staff received training in how to look after vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Minimum training requirement should include: - Move shipment from apron to covered area immediately after unloading. - If customs clearance takes more than 24 hrs, place vaccines in +2C to +8C cold room - NEVER place vaccine or diluents in a freezer room. IATA provides such training (www.iata.org/training/courses/Pages/temperature-sensitive-cargo-tcgp63.aspx).

input.label: Notes:

select1.label: E1:11a If any vaccines require customs clearance. Is there a document or other evidence of a formal contingency plan in place in case of unexpected arrival delays (of more than 6 hours)
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Delays include 1) flight delay; 2) delay at a border crossing, 3) delay in transport to the primary store. Flight delays are ultimately the responsibility of the shipper but may affect availability of national staff to meet the delayed flight. Contingency plan should include requirement for receiving staff to be available at night or during weekends and emergency arrangements for rapid clearance through customs and/or moving vaccines to a suitable cold room.

input.label: Notes:

select1.label: E1:12a If any vaccines come from an international source. Does removal of vaccine from the port of entry typically take more than 24 hours? [If Y, complete E1:13a, otherwise go to E1:14a].
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: The relevant issue here is removal of the vaccine shipment from the port of entry. In some countries customs clearance takes place at the primary vaccine store and this process may take more than 24 hours.

input.label: Notes:
E1:13a If customs clearance takes more than 24 hours. Airport, sea port or border crossing cold room checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Indicator covers arrivals by air, sea or land.

select1.label: A. Is a +2C to +8C cold room available to hold vaccine before its removal to the primary store?
B. Is the cold room big enough to accommodate the largest anticipated vaccine shipment?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Cold rooms at airports or sea ports are likely to be large enough to accommodate vaccine shipments because they are used for many other purposes. There is unlikely to be a cold room available at a road-based border crossing. Check capacity only if the cold room is small. In some cases the temporary holding store may be operated by the clearing agent or a wholesaler, rather than the port of entry.

select1.label: C. Does the cold room have a continuous temperature recording device?
D. Can the cold room be locked?
E. Are there credible temperature records showing at least twice daily temperature monitoring?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Manual checking twice daily, 7 days a week, with records, is a minimum standard. Check records at known times of vaccine arrival over the past 12 months. Check continuous records, if available. 'Credible' records will show variation in temperature and variations in handwriting.

input.label: E1:13a Notes:

select1.label: E1:14a If any vaccines require customs clearance. Is there documentary evidence that vaccines are transported from the airport or border crossing to the primary store under temperature-controlled conditions (active or passive cooling)
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check status of electronic shipping indicator records. These should demonstrate whether temperature excursions have occurred during customs clearance and transport to the primary store. The most likely cause of an excursion is excessive delay leading to loss of coolant in the shipping containers.

input.label: Notes:

select1.label: E1:15a Are syringes and safety boxes procured direct from a supplier or manufacturer?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Supply and distribution of consumables (syringes and safety boxes) are not always the direct responsibility of the immunization programme. However, these products are so important that the assessor should make every effort to investigate the supply chain. Answer 'Y' if consumables are received direct from the supplier or manufacturer.

input.label: Notes:
E1:16a From where are these consumables procured?
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Complete A to D if the answer to E1:15a is 'Y'.

select1.label: A. Via a UN source (e.g. UNICEF-SD or PAHO)
B. From an international distribution warehouse
C. Direct from international manufacturer(s)
D. Direct from in-country manufacturer(s)

input.label: Notes:
E1:17a If any consumables require customs clearance. Customs clearance checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Satisfactory' working arrangements may exist with customs staff on an informal basis, but this relies entirely on personal relationships. Ideally there should be a Memorandum of Understanding with Customs, setting out their responsibilities for clearing vaccine and looking after it correctly whilst it is at the port of entry.

select1.label: A. Are the working arrangements with customs satisfactory?
B. Does an SOP or MoU document specify working procedures with customs?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: An SOP is the best way to detail the responsibilities of the parties. There may also be a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU). However, an MoU is of no operational significance unless it describes the responsibilities of the parties.

select1.label: C. Are the procedures set out in the SOP or MoU thorough and complete?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Thorough and complete' means that the SOP or MoU sets out the responsibilities of the parties and agreed response times. Consumables should be moved from the port of entry to the primary store as soon as possible, preferably within a defined maximum time period).

select1.label: D. Are agreed procedures followed?

input.label: E1:17a Notes:
E1:18b If consumables are procured direct from a supplier or manufacturer. Does the local Product Arrival Form (PAR) include the following procedures for checking consumables?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: There should be an SOP and a standard form for checking products on arrival. See EVM Model SOP: EVM-SOP-E1-03 - Product arrival procedures.

select1.label: A. PAR Part I - Advance notice section
B. PAR Part II - Arrival details
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Syringes have lot numbers and expiry dates which should be recorded and entered in the stock records in order to ensure correct EEFO handling throughout the in-country supply chain.

select1.label: C. PAR Part III - Shipment details
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Electronic temperature indicators have a maximum shelf life before activation - this affects their subsequent operating life. Consequently, they should be distributed and used in order of manufacturing date.

select1.label: D. PAR Part IV - Documentation checklist
E. PAR Part V - General condition of shipment
F. PAR Part VI - Inspection supervisor signature

input.label: Notes:
E1:19a If consumables are procured direct from a supplier or manufacturer. Assess product arrival reports (PARs) received during the review period:
A. How many individual product arrivals have there been?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: The EVM Model SOP also refers to cold chain equipment. These products need not be included in the PAR assessment.

input.label: B. There should be a PAR accompanying each product. Record the number of PARs that were actually received.
C. Record how many of these received PARs were completed correctly by the 'Inspection Supervisor'.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Completed correctly' means that the PAR must have been completed in full. The PAR and related documents (e.g. pre-shipment advice, conformity certificates, etc.) should be filed together.

input.label: Notes:

group.label: E2 All vaccines & diluents are stored within WHO-recommended temperature ranges.

input.label: E2:01a Temperature monitoring study checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Refer to WHO/IVB/05.01 Rev 1: Study protocol for temperature monitoring in the cold chain

select1.label: A. Has a systematic temperature monitoring study been carried out within the past 5 years?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2011/WHO_IVB_05.01_REV.1_eng.pdf

input.label: B. Have the recommendations in the study report been implemented [Score on a scale of 0-4 based on the proportion of recommendations implemented and the time elapsed since the study. Elaborate in the notes].
input.hint: Guidance Notes: A temperature study gives an indication of: 1) Environmental challenges along distribution and storage routes/points including average time of distribution/storage; 2) Cold chain efficiency of distribution containers and vehicles; 3) Cold chain efficiency of management/equipment during distribution and storage. Recommendations are typically aimed at route planning, equipment and human resources, management follow-up action and overall reliability of cold chain maintenance. In scoring this indicator, use judgement based on the time elapsed since the study and the extent of implementation of the recommendations.

input.label: E2:01a Notes:
E2:02a If there are cold rooms and/or freezer rooms. Temperature mapping checklist:
A. How many vaccine cold rooms and freezer rooms are there?
B. How many of these rooms have a fully documented temperature mapping study?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Mapping should be repeated whenever changes are made which increase loading or affect air circulation, or when refrigeration equipment is replaced. This is essential for cold rooms and desirable for freezer rooms. Enquire whether mapping has been repeated and record in notes box.

input.label: E2:02a Notes:

select1.label: E2:03a Can the storekeeper(s) or health worker(s) give the correct storage temperature range for each of the vaccines on the schedule? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Knowledge of correct storage temperatures is vital. If ANY of the respondents give any incorrect answers, score 'No'. Note also: 1) If s/he says that freeze-dried vaccines should be stored at -20C record this as 'Yes'. Current WHO advice is to store these vaccines at +2 to + 8C, but storage at -20C will not damage these vaccines. 2) If s/he say that freeze-dried vaccines packed with diluents can be stored at -20C, this answer MUST be scored as 'No'. 3) At service point level, it is correct to say that all vaccines can be stored at +2 to +8C.

input.label: Notes:

select1.label: E2:04a Do the storekeeper(s) or health worker(s) know which vaccines on the schedule can be damaged by temperatures below 0C?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: It is essential that respondents know which of the vaccines should not be exposed to temperatures below 0C. It is not important that they know the precise freezing temperature of each of these vaccines.

input.label: Notes:

select1.label: E2:06a Can the storekeeper or health worker demonstrate correct reading of all types of thermometer and/or temperature recording device(s) used in the store?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Ask the storekeeper or health worker to demonstrate correct practice. A stem or dial thermometer must be held correctly so as to avoid parallax errors. Interpolation of values between the printed numbers on the temperature scale must be accurate. Interpretation of readings taken from chart recorders and electronic recording devices must be correct.

input.label: Notes:
E2:07b If there is refrigeration equipment. Temperature record checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: This question does NOT apply in health facilities where cold boxes or vaccine carriers are used to store vaccine temporarily.

select1.label: A. Are refrigeration temperatures recorded manually?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Daily manual recording of the temperatures of refrigeration equipment allows the store keeper/health worker/supervisor to: a. verify whether the storage temperature is within the acceptable temperature ranges of +2C to +8C in cold rooms and vaccine refrigerators and - 25C to -15C in the freezer room and freezers, b. detect temperature alarm conditions which may have caused vaccine damage and to take appropriate action, and, c. assess the performance over time of vaccine handling at each link of the cold chain and to monitor the performance of cold chain equipment.

select1.label: B. Are the manual temperature records complete (twice daily, every day) for each and every cold room, freezer room, vaccine refrigerator and vaccine freezer throughout the review period?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Complete' means there are temperature records (AM and PM) for every day of the review period for each appliance.

select1.label: C. Does the temperature record form include space for entering alarm events? [Y, N. Enter n/a if only stem or dial thermometers are used]
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Enter n/a if only stem or dial thermometers are used. If 30-day refrigerator loggers are used, the form must be designed to record alarm events. If the form is inadequate please comment in the Notes section.

input.label: Notes:

select1.label: E2:08a If there are cold rooms and/or freezer rooms. Is there a complete set of temperature recorder discs and/or temperature logger printouts for each and every cold room and freezer room throughout the review period?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: This question only applies in facilities with cold rooms and/or freezer rooms.

input.label: Notes:

select1.label: E2:09a If refrigerated vehicles are used. Is there a complete set of temperature recorder traces and/or temperature logger printouts for each and every refrigerated vehicle throughout the review period?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: This question only applies in facilities which directly operate refrigerated vehicles.

input.label: Notes:

select1.label: E2:10a If there are cold rooms or freezer rooms. Does a random 7 day sample of temperature recorder traces/logger printouts for each cold room and freezer room agree with the matching manual temperature records? [Y, N. Answer No if there are no temperature recorder traces/logger printouts to review].
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Select a random 7 day period for each appliance (not the same period for each). Check the twice daily temperature records against the corresponding times on the temperature trace. If the record is consistently within 2C of the trace, this is acceptable. If there are significant discrepancies, especially if the temperature record is uniform and the trace is not, interview staff to establish the reasons.

input.label: Notes:

select1.label: E2:11a If there is refrigeration equipment. Have temperature records been kept in a safe place for at least three years?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Countries should be encouraged to retain such records for tracing purposes. If records are not available for three years, review the records kept since the immunization programme adopted EVSM or EVM.

input.label: Notes:
E2:12a If there is refrigeration equipment. Temperature and alarm event review checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: There must be a written record of these reviews which identifies problems and records actions taken. A verbal assurance is not sufficient.

select1.label: A. Are temperature records and alarm events formally reviewed at least once a month in order to identify temperature excursions and their causes?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check whether records are reviewed and recorded. 'Excursions' are temperatures below +2C or above +8C for cold rooms and vaccine refrigerators, and above -5C for freezer rooms and vaccine freezers.

select1.label: B. If temperature records and alarm events are formally reviewed at least once a month, is there documentary evidence that remedial action has been taken in response to excursions or breakdowns? [Y, N, n/a if there are no excursions or breakdowns]
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Enter n/a if there are no excursions or breakdowns. Interview the responsible person. Discuss and evaluate remedial actions taken. Inspect maintenance records.

input.label: E2:12a Notes:
E2:13b If there are cold rooms and/or freezer rooms or refrigerated vehicle(s).
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Since calibration is a relatively complex and technical process it should be avoided wherever possible by choosing temperature monitoring devices which retain their calibration for extended periods, or which can be recalibrated automatically - e.g. by replacing a digital sensor. For service delivery level equipment calibration is impractical. However stem thermometers hold their calibration well and Fridge-tags are effectively calibrated for life (2-3 years). Bi-metallic dial thermometers loose calibration quite easily and are now excluded from PQS.

select1.label: A. Is there a test calibration record to show that the cold rooms , freezer rooms and refrigerated vehicle (if used) are calibrated every 12 months?
B. Check on site with a calibrated device next to the sensor(s). Is the temperature within 1C of the indicated room temperature(s)?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Place a calibrated device in contact with the room sensor(s). Compare the temperature reading with the temperature shown on the temperature display outside the room.

input.label: Notes:

group.label: E3 Cold storage, dry storage and transport capacity is sufficient to accommodate all vaccines and supplies needed for the programme.

input.label: E3:01a If there is refrigeration equipment. Using data from the annual vaccine arrival schedule (primary level) and the annual vaccine delivery schedule (lower levels), establish whether the capacity of the +2C to + 8C vaccine store is sufficient over a one year cycle. Where relevant, include other products and supplementary vaccines.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Record the make and model of all refrigeration equipment in the Notes section below, then use the EVM Assistant tool to perform the calculations. Record any equipment which is still in its packaging or has not been installed, and any equipment which is broken but repairable, but do NOT include any of this equipment in the capacity calculation. The net storage capacity is acceptable if it is greater than the estimated maximum volume of vaccine to be stored.

input.label: A. What is the net storage capacity of the +2C to + 8C store(s) in litres or m.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: See the Refrig_freezer worksheet in the EVM Assistant for the vaccine storage capacities of refrigerators. If the refrigerator is not listed, measure the net storage capacity of the refrigerator. See the EVM Assistant user guide for calculation methods. Worksheet_A of the EVM Assistant may be used for calculating the net storage capacity of cold rooms.

input.label: B. What is the estimated maximum vaccine volume in litres or m.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the EVM Assistant to perform this calculation.

input.label: C. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (3 months)
D. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (6 months)
E. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume (including Pentavalent vaccine) in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)
F. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume (including Pentavalent vaccine) in liters or m3, plus 10% (3 months)
G. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume (including Pentavalent vaccine) in liters or m3, plus 10% (6 months)
E3:01a Notes:

E3:02a If there is refrigeration equipment. Using data from the annual vaccine arrival schedule (primary store) and the annual vaccine delivery schedule (lower levels), establish whether the capacity of the -20C vaccine store is sufficient over a one year cycle. Where relevant, include other products and supplementary vaccines.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Record the make and model of all refrigeration equipment in the Notes section below, then use the EVM Assistant tool to perform the calculations. Record any equipment which is still in its packaging or has not been installed, and any equipment which is broken but repairable, but do NOT include any of this equipment in the capacity calculation. The net storage capacity is acceptable if it is greater than the estimated maximum volume of vaccine to be stored.

select1.label: A. Is any vaccine stored at -20C in this store?

input.label: B. What is the net storage capacity of the -20C store(s) in litres or m.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: See the Refrig_freezer worksheet in the EVM Assistant for the vaccine storage capacities of freezers. If the freezer is not listed, measure the net storage capacity of the freezer. See the EVM Assistant user guide for calculation methods. Worksheet_A of the EVM Assistant may be used for calculating the net storage capacity of freezer rooms.

input.label: C. What is the estimated maximum vaccine volume in litres or m.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the EVM Assistant to perform this calculation.

input.label: D. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (3 months)
input.hint: The store capacity, taking account of utilization factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: E. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (6 months)
E3:02a Notes:

E3:03a If syringes and safety boxes (consumables) are stored at this level. Using data from the annual consumables arrival schedule (primary level) and the annual consumables delivery schedule (lower levels), establish whether the capacity of the dry store is sufficient over a one year cycle.
input.hint: Collect site data, then use the EVM Assistant to perform the calculations. The dry store is often housed in a separate building and may be used to store other products in addition to EPI syringes and safety boxes, etc. Judgement and enquiry may be needed to establish whether capacity is sufficient. Ignore diluents in the volume calculation if the dry store is only used to store syringes and safety boxes. Diluents should be stored in the vaccine store itself. The net storage capacity is acceptable if it is greater than the estimated maximum volume of diluent, syringes and safety boxes to be stored.

input.label: A. What is the net storage capacity of the dry store in litres or m.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: See the EVM Assistant user guide for calculation methods. Worksheet_A of the EVM Assistant may be used for calculating the net storage capacity of dry stores with shelving.

input.label: B. What is the estimated maximum diluent, syringe and safety box volume in litres or m.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the EVM Assistant to perform this calculation.

input.label: C. Enter maximum estimated diluent, syringe and safety box volumes liters or m, plus 10%. (3 months)
D. Enter maximum estimated diluent, syringe and safety box volumes liters or m, plus 10%. (6 months)
E3:03a Notes:
E3:08a If vaccine transport is directly operated by this store. Using data from the vaccine delivery schedule, establish whether transport capacity is sufficient to meet peak demand levels.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Record the make and model, or provide a description, of all vaccine transport vehicles in the Notes section below, then use the EVM Assistant to perform the calculations. The net transport capacity is acceptable if it is greater than the estimated maximum volume of vaccine to be transported.

input.label: A. What is the net storage capacity of the delivery vehicle(s) in litres or m.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Worksheet_C of the EVM Assistant may be used for calculating the storage capacity of vaccine transport vehicles.

input.label: B. What is the maximum delivery volume in litres or m.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the EVM Assistant to perform this calculation.

input.label: Notes:

E3:09a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Using data from the vaccine delivery schedule, fixed session size data or outreach session size data, establish whether coolant pack storage capacities are sufficient to meet maximum demand levels.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Coolant packs contain either water (water-packs) or another phase change material (PCM-packs). Water packs are either frozen (ice-packs) or cooled to between +2C and +8C (cool-packs). PCM-packs change phase at about +5C and eliminate the freezing risk associated with ice-packs. Record the make and model of all refrigeration equipment in the Notes section below, then use the EVM Assistant tool to perform the calculations. Record any equipment which is still in its packaging or has not been installed, and any equipment which is broken but repairable, but do NOT include any of this equipment in the capacity calculation. The net storage capacities are acceptable if they are greater than the maximum daily demands.

select1.label: A. Are conditioned ice-packs used?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Conditioned ice-packs may be used for the distribution of vaccines to lower levels, for outreach, or for on-site immunization sessions.

input.label: B. What is the available ice-pack storage capacity of all ice-pack freezers (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: See the Refrig_freezer worksheet in the EVM Assistant for the coolant-pack storage capacities of freezers. If the freezer is not listed, measure the net storage capacity.

input.label: C. What is the maximum daily demand for ice-packs (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the EVM Assistant to perform this calculation.

select1.label: D. Are cool-packs used?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Cool-packs may be used for the distribution of vaccines to lower levels, for outreach, or for on-site immunization sessions.

input.label: E. What is the available cool-pack storage capacity of all cool-pack refrigerators (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: See the Refrig_freezer worksheet in the EVM Assistant for the coolant-pack storage capacities of refrigerators. If the refrigerator is not listed, measure the net storage capacity.

input.label: F. What is the maximum daily demand for cool-packs (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the EVM Assistant to perform this calculation.

input.label: E3:09a Notes:

E3:10a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Using data from the vaccine delivery or collection schedule, or outreach session size data, establish whether there are sufficient passive containers to meet maximum demand levels.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Check total vaccine storage capacity of available passive containers and compare against delivery schedule. If containers are always supplied by the receiving store this question is not applicable here but must be assessed at the next level down in the supply chain.

select1.label: A. Are passive containers kept for vaccine collection, delivery or outreach?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Answer 'Y' if the store keeps a stock of passive containers. If delivery and collection dates are staggered, the same containers may be used for both purposes.

input.label: B. What is the total vaccine storage capacity of all available passive containers (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: If some containers are in use, check the container inventory to establish how many there should be.

input.label: C. What is the maximum daily passive container vaccine storage capacity required (litres)?
E3:10a Notes:
E3:11a If there is refrigeration equipment. Vaccine store contingency planning checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Contingency plans are context-specific, but should include the following minimum elements: 1) Identify the major sources of risk (e.g. power failure, flood, earthquake, etc.). 2) Prepare a written contingency plan. 3) Post emergency contact details on the noticeboard in the vaccine store. Details must be visible to passers by in case the store is locked 4) Staff must know that the universal safe storage temperature for ALL vaccines in an emergency is +2C to +8C.

select1.label: A. Is there a satisfactory SOP which sets out a contingency plan in the event of equipment failure or other emergency? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: 5) Identify at least two alternative cold storage locations. Inspect them to make sure they are large enough, well-managed, and can maintain correct temperatures. At sub-national stores cold boxes are not a satisfactory emergency solution.

select1.label: B. Are emergency contact details posted in the vaccine store? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: 6) Ensure that there is a written agreement with the selected emergency providers. If payment will be required, make sure that this can be funded. 7) Regularly rehearse the contingency plan with store staff and the emergency providers.

select1.label: C. Do staff know what to do in the event of an emergency? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: All staff should know what to do in the event of fire. Where relevant, staff should also know what to do in the event of temperature alarms, mains power failure and refrigerator failure. Use the Notes section to record responses.

input.label: Notes:

group.label: E4 Buildings, cold chain equipment and transport systems enable the vaccine and consumables supply chain to function well

input.label: E4:01a Vaccine store site checklist:

select1.label: A. Can delivery vehicles reach the store(s) loading area or loading dock? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A loading area is a designated parking bay immediately outside the store. A loading dock is a covered area which the vehicle can back into. In larger stores, it may be raised to the level of the vehicle's load compartment.

select1.label: B. Is the site secure? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A secure site requires a fenced compound with 24 hour guarding or surveillance.

input.label: Notes:
E4:02a Dry storage on a separate site. Dry store site checklist.

select1.label: A. Can delivery vehicles reach the store(s) loading area or loading dock? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A loading area is a designated parking bay immediately outside the store. A loading dock is a covered area which the vehicle can back into. In larger stores, it may be raised to the level of the vehicle's load compartment.

select1.label: B. Is the site secure? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A secure site requires a fenced compound with 24 hour guarding or surveillance.

input.label: Notes:
E4:03a Vaccine store or health facility building checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Vaccine store' in this context includes service point health facilities.

select1.label: A. Is the vaccine store building suitable for the climate? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Suitable' means one of the following: 1) Cold or temperate climates: Thermally insulated and heated. 2) Hot, wet climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned. Well protected against rain penetration. 3) Hot, dry climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned and/or passively protected against excessive heat build up. Protected against dust penetration.

select1.label: B. Is the roof finish in good condition and with no internal evidence of leaks?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Roof leaks': Check for damp stains on ceilings.

select1.label: C. Are the external walls free of severe cracks or other major damage? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Severe crack': A crack 5mm or greater in width which extends through the thickness of the wall. 'Major damage': Includes distortion due to subsidence or damage caused by earthquakes.

select1.label: D. Are windows and external doors in good condition and secure (grilles and/or locks)? .
E. Are floors dry and reasonably level? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Reasonably level': The floor should not be visibly sloping and it should be smooth enough for small wheeled pallet trucks.

select1.label: F. Are there any fire extinguishers and have they been tested in the past 12 months?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Fire extinguishers should be tested and certified annually. There should be a label on each one showing the test date. Fire extinguishers are unlikely to be found in small health facilities, so enter 'n/a'.

select1.label: G. Is the electrical system satisfactory?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Satisfactory' means that wiring, circuit breakers, electrical sockets and light fittings are in good condition and securely fixed in place. All circuits should be properly earthed. In a full inspection the earthing of sockets can be checked with a ring main tester. If there are any doubts, a professional inspection should be carried out. Lowest delivery and service point facilities may have no electricity. If this is the case, score 'n/a'.

select1.label: H.Is the drainage system working (both rainwater and foul drainage)? .
J. Is the air-conditioning system working?
K. Is the heating system working?

input.label: Notes:
E4:04a Separate dry store building. Building checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: If there is more than one 'other' building, use this checklist and the notes box to cover them all.

select1.label: A. Is the dry store building suitable for the climate? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Suitable' means one of the following: 1) Cold or temperate climates: Thermally insulated and heated. 2) Hot, wet climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned. Well protected against rain penetration. 3) Hot, dry climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned and/or passively protected against excessive heat build up. Protected against dust penetration.

select1.label: B. Is the roof finish in good condition and with no internal evidence of leaks?
C. Are the external walls free of severe cracks or other major damage? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Severe crack': A crack 5mm or greater in width which extends through the thickness of the wall. 'Major damage': Includes distortion due to subsidence or damage caused by earthquakes.

select1.label: D. Are windows and external doors in good condition and secure (grilles and/or locks)? .
E. Are floors dry and reasonably level? .
F. Are there any fire extinguishers and have been tested in the past 12 months? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Fire extinguishers should be tested and certified annually. There should be a label on each one showing the test date.

select1.label: G. Is the electrical system satisfactory?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Lowest delivery and service point facilities may have no electricity. If this is the case, score 'n/a'.

select1.label: H. Is the drainage system working (both rainwater and foul drainage)? .
J. Is the air-conditioning system working?
K. Is the heating system working?

input.label: Notes:
E4:05a If there is refrigeration equipment Refrigeration equipment space checklist
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Ventilation requirements are climate-dependent and also depend on the type of refrigeration equipment installed. Refrigerators, freezers and cold/freezer rooms with through-the-wall (monobloc) cooling units discharge waste heat into the room and must be well ventilated. Split system cooling units discharge waste heat to the outside air, which avoids waste heat build up in the room. Natural ventilation works best if there is a low level air inlet and a high level outlet, preferably on opposite sides of the room. Note: Ventilation will only lower the room air temperature if the outside air is cooler than the inside air. During the daytime in hot dry climates, natural ventilation may actually increase the internal air temperature. In these climates night time ventilation is the most effective way to cool a room naturally.

select1.label: A. Is there sufficient space to maintain the equipment?
B. Is the room well ventilated?

input.label: Notes:
E4:06a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Packing area checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: It is rather difficult to assess packing area temperature as it depends on climate, building design, building construction and time of inspection. In temperate climates there is unlikely to be a problem. In cold winter/temperate summer climates, the presence of a permanent heating system should ensure correct temperatures. In cold winter/hot summer (continental) climates heating is needed in winter and air-conditioning is likely to be needed in summer. In hot humid climates indoor temperature is likely to be similar to the outdoor shade temperature unless there is air-conditioning.

select1.label: A. Is the packing area close to the refrigeration equipment area? .
B. Are the ice-pack freezers or cool-pack/PCM-pack coolers close to the packing area? .
C. Is there sufficient lay out space for conditioning ice-packs?
D. Are the empty containers stored in, or close to, the packing area?
E. Is there sufficient lay out space for packing vaccines into containers? .
F. Is there sufficient space to store packed containers? .
G. Are there working hand washing or hand sanitizing facilities in, or close to the packing area? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Working' hand washing facilities means that at least cold water comes out of the tap. Hand sanitizer means a wall-mounted device filled with antiseptic gel.

select1.label: H. Can the temperature of the packing area be maintained between 15 and 25C throughout the year? .
J. Is the packing area protected against direct sunlight? .

input.label: Notes:
E4:07a If refrigerated vehicles are used. Packing area checklist:

select1.label: A. Is the packing area close to the refrigeration equipment area? .
B. Are the delivery cartons or delivery crates stored in or close to the packing area?
C. Is there sufficient lay out space to assemble vaccine orders for packing into delivery cartons or delivery crates? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Sufficient space' means that there is a clearly designated area with work benches where an order can be assembled and packed in a continuous uninterrupted operation. The amount of space required for a specific store is a matter of judgement.

select1.label: D. Can packed vaccines be loaded directly into the refrigerated vehicle? .
E. Are there hand washing facilities in, or close to the packing area? .
F. Can the temperature of the packing area be maintained between 15 and 25C throughout the year? .
G. Is the packing area protected against direct sunlight? .

input.label: Notes:
E4:08a Store keeper's office checklist

select1.label: A. Is the office close to the vaccine storage area, packing area and loading bay? .
B. Is the room large enough? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A minimum of 7.5m is recommended for a single storekeeper. The room needs to be larger if there is more than one person working in the office.

input.label: Notes:
E4:09a Vaccine store: secondary storage space checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Note: 'Secondary storage space' is an area in the vaccine store assigned for diluents and the like. It is not the same as the 'dry store' which is used for syringes and safety boxes.

select1.label: A. Is there enough storage space for diluents? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Diluents should be stored as close as possible to the vaccine.

select1.label: B. Is there enough storage space for packaging cartons or packaging crates?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Packaging should be kept close to the packing area.

select1.label: C. Is there enough storage space for cold boxes or passive containers?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Cold boxes should be kept close to the packing area.

select1.label: D. Is there enough storage space for consumables (spare parts, freeze indicators, stationary, etc)? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Consumables need to be accessible, but it is not essential for them to be kept in the vaccine store itself.

input.label: Notes:
E4:10b If there is a dry store. Dry store checklist:

select1.label: A. Does the dry store have well organised shelving, pallet standing or pallet racking?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: In a 'pallet standing' store pallets are stored directly on the floor.

select1.label: B. Is there suitable mechanical handling equipment, if needed?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Suitable' mechanical handling equipment means pallet lifters in pallet standing stores and forklifts in high rise (pallet racking) stores. High rise shelving stores require safe and stable step ladders as a minimum.

select1.label: C. If there is suitable mechanical handling equipment, is the equipment in working order?

input.label: E4:10b Notes:
E4:11b If there are cold rooms and/or freezer rooms. Cold room and freezer room checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Ignore any equipment which is out-of-service for a legitimate reason - for example because it is being serviced or repaired. Check that any vaccine that was stored in the out-of-service equipment is being kept under safe conditions.

select1.label: A. Are all cold room and freezer room enclosures in good condition at time of inspection? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Good condition' means free of corrosion, with all panel joints properly sealed and no sign of excessive condensation or ice build-up on the face of the panels.

select1.label: B. Are all cold rooms and all freezer rooms fitted with dual refrigeration units? .
C. If all cold rooms and freezer rooms are fitted with dual refrigeration units, is there a duty sharing system for the dual units, either manual or automatic?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Duty sharing': Alternative approaches are 1) manual changeover between units on a periodic basis - typically weekly or monthly; automatic changeover on a periodic basis. 2) Different set-point temperatures for each unit in the pair so that one unit runs more than the other.

select1.label: D. Can doors be locked from the outside but freely opened from the inside? .
E. Are all rooms fitted with sufficient good quality shelving? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Shelving should be strong enough to support the vaccine without sagging. Preferably it should be supplied by the cold room manufacturer.

select1.label: F. Cold climates only. Do cold rooms EITHER have low temperature protection OR are they located in a permanently heated room?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: In the winter in cold climates there is a risk that the vaccine will freeze inside the cold room. To prevent this, the cold room should EITHER have a low temperature protection circuit OR the room in which the cold room is located should be permanently heated.

input.label: Notes:
E4:12a If there are cold rooms and/or freezer rooms. Checklist for working in cold rooms and freezer rooms:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: See: User's handbook for vaccine cold rooms and freezer rooms. WHO/V&B/02.31. Without warm clothing it is unsafe to work in a cold room or freezer room for extended periods. Some tasks, such as physical stock counts, cannot be carried out without this protection.

select1.label: A. Is warm clothing available for cold store workers? .
B. Have workers received training in safe working in cold stores? .

input.label: Notes:
E4:13b If there are refrigerators and/or freezers. Vaccine freezer/refrigerator checklist.

select1.label: A. Do all vaccine freezers comply with the WHO specifications that were in force at date of purchase, including correct climate zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check that the equipment's climate rating is correct for the site.

select1.label: B. Do all vaccine refrigerators comply with the WHO specifications that were in force at date of purchase, including correct climate zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check that the equipment's climate rating is correct for the site. PIS and PQS pre-qualified equipment should have a sticker to show the climate rating.

select1.label: C. Are all ice-lined refrigerators fitted with the correct vaccine storage baskets?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Chest ILRs must always be fitted with baskets so that vaccine does not come into contact with the bottom or walls of the unit because this can freeze vaccine.

select1.label: D. For electric and solar equipment only: Are there sufficient daily hours of electricity for the installed equipment throughout the year?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Sufficient daily hours of electricity' depends on the type of refrigeration equipment installed - >20 hrs per day for domestic and absorption units; >8 hrs per day for normal ILRs; >4 hrs per day for high efficiency ILRs. Solar systems, whether direct drive, or with batteries, must be correctly sized for the location.

select1.label: E. For kerosene and gas equipment only: Is there sufficient availability of kerosene and/or gas throughout the year?
F. For cold climates only: Do vaccine refrigerators EITHER have low temperature protection OR are they located in a permanently heated room?

input.label: Notes:
E4:14a If there is refrigeration equipment. Inspect refrigeration equipment:
A. How many refrigeration units are there (dual CR and FR units count as 2, refrigerators and freezers count as 1 each)?
B. How many of these are CFC-free?
Notes:
E4:15a Standby generator.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: There should always be a standby generator at the primary store unless mains electricity is completely reliable and/or has a backup supply from a separate transformer. The same requirement applies at sub-national stores equipped with cold rooms. Generators are not required in small sub-national stores, lowest delivery level and service point stores where ice-lined refrigerators are used and there is at least 8 hours electricity per day. Generators are also not required where kerosene, gas or solar refrigerators are used or where a health facility uses cold boxes or vaccine carriers for storing vaccine.

select1.label: A. Is a generator required at this store?
B. Is a standby generator installed and connected to the vaccine store?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: If a generator is installed but is not required then the generator questions are switched off and need not be answered.

input.label: E4:15a Notes:
E4:16a If a generator is required and installed. Standby generator checklist:

select1.label: A. Is the generator in working order? .
B. Does the generator have a working auto-start system?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: There should be a mains failure auto-start system so that the generator starts automatically when there is a power cut. Ideally, there should be an auto-stop system when mains power returns.

select1.label: C. Can the generator start all the connected equipment in the vaccine store? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: The starting load for a refrigeration compressor is much higher than the running load. Ask for a demonstration to prove that the generator is able to cope with the combined starting load of all connected refrigeration units. Well-designed systems may have 'smart switching' which reduces the starting load by automatically phasing in the individual refrigeration units.

select1.label: D. Is the fuel tank large enough? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: 72 hours continuous running is recommended, but this is context-dependent. If power cuts are short and/or fuel is readily available, a smaller capacity will be acceptable. The way to assess this is as follows: 1) Establish the longest power cut experienced during the review period. 2) Check the generator fuel consumption in litres per hour. 3) Check the capacity of the fuel tank. If tank capacity/consumption per hour is less than the longest power cut then the tank capacity is too small.

select1.label: E. Are there sufficient reserve supplies of fuel? .
F. Is the generator in a secure compound? .

input.label: E4:16a Notes:

select1.label: E4:17a Is the voltage fluctuation sufficiently severe to require voltage regulation equipment?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Voltage regulation equipment on all refrigeration equipment is essential if voltage fluctuations exceed 15%. Obtain information from an electrical engineer, or from the local supply company. In some settings, UPS systems (Uninterrupted Power Supply) may substitute for voltage regulators. These units also provide a limited period of back-up power.

input.label: Notes:
E4:18a If voltage regulation is required. Voltage regulator checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: If there is no refrigeration equipment in a particular category - e.g. 'freezer room', enter 0 for the equipment number and 0 for the voltage regulator number.

input.label: A. How many freezer rooms are there?
B. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: There may be a single central voltage regulator for the vaccine store or some sharing arrangement across multiple appliances. In this case score on the basis that every piece of equipment has a regulator and make a note in the comment box.

input.label: C. How many cold rooms are there?
D. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator of the correct type?
E. How many vaccine refrigerators and vaccine freezers are there?
F. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator of the correct type?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Solar refrigerators do not require voltage regulators. Absorption refrigerators require a different type of voltage regulator to those used for compression refrigerators. This needs to be checked during the inspection.

input.label: Notes:
E4:19b If there are cold rooms and/or freezer rooms. Temperature monitoring equipment checklist:

select1.label: A. Do all cold rooms and freezer rooms have fully functioning continuous temperature recorders? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Fully functioning': Electronic temperature recorders, all attached sensors, and any associated computer equipment are fully operational. Chart recorders have functional pens and an adequate supply of spare pens and blank paper discs.

select1.label: B. Are the temperature sensor(s) located so as to monitor warm and cold spots in the vaccine storage zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Correct location or locations for temperature monitoring sensors should be established by temperature mapping during cold room/freezer room commissioning. Small rooms up to 40 m usually have a single sensor. Larger rooms should have two or more sensors.

input.label: Notes:
E4:20b If there are vaccine freezers. Temperature monitoring equipment checklist:

select1.label: A. If this is a primary store, do all vaccine freezers have working continuous temperature recorders?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Computerized temperature monitoring systems in vaccine freezers are essential at primary store level. Note that 30-day refrigerator loggers are not designed to be used in freezers.

select1.label: B. Do all vaccine freezers have a working thermometer stored with the vaccine? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: All freezers should have a stem or dial thermometer.

input.label: Notes:
E4:21b If there are vaccine refrigerators. Temperature monitoring equipment checklist:

select1.label: A. Do all vaccine refrigerators have working continuous temperature recorders or refrigerator loggers? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Computer-connected temperature monitoring systems or 30-day refrigerator loggers are essential at PR, SN and LD levels and are highly recommended at SP level. Freeze indicators are a useful backup but they are single-use devices and they cannot identify when a freezing event occurs.

select1.label: B. Do all vaccine refrigerators have a working thermometer stored with the vaccine? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A stem or dial thermometer provides essential backup in case the continuous monitoring device fails.

input.label: Notes:
E4:22b If there are cold rooms and/or freezer rooms. Temperature alarm equipment checklist for cold rooms and freezer rooms:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Ideally alarm systems should also have an external flashing light and/or alarm sounder so that security guards are alerted after working hours and an auto-dialler system to alert responsible staff by landline or mobile phone.

input.label: A. How many freezer rooms are there?
B. How many have functioning alarm systems?
C. How many are connected to an auto-dialler system?
D. How many cold rooms are there?
E. How many have functioning alarm systems?
F. How many are connected to an auto-dialler system?
Notes:
E4:23b If there are refrigerators or freezers used for storing vaccine. Centralised temperature alarm equipment checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: This question is only applicable at primary level.

input.label: A. How many vaccine refrigerators and vaccine freezers are there?
B. How many have functioning alarm systems?
C. How many are connected to an auto-dialler system?
Notes:

select1.label: E4:24b Are telecommunications links adequate for the facility and in working order?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Telecommunications links include fixed line telephone, fax, mobile telephone and internet. Primary and sub-national stores should have a telephone with fax and/or internet. Mobile telephones are acceptable for lower level facilities provide call costs are paid for by the programme. Radio links may be acceptable at these facilities if there is no other alternative.

input.label: Notes:
E4:25a If vaccine transport is directly operated by this store. General vehicle checklist (excludes refrigerated vehicles):
input.hint: Guidance Notes: This checklist is written with road vehicles in mind. Some programmes may own and operate boats. If this situation is encountered, evaluate boats using this indicator. If transport is provided by a parastatal or private sector contractor try to inspect their vehicles, especially if refrigerated vehicles are used.

select1.label: A. Is every vehicle, for which the programme is responsible, in good mechanical condition? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Ignore vehicles that are scheduled for disposal.

select1.label: B. Does every vehicle, for which the programme is responsible, have its own user logbook? .
C. Does every vehicle, for which the programme is responsible, have an up to date maintenance and service record (including a record of refrigeration unit servicing where applicable)? .
D. Is fuel available throughout the year

input.label: Notes:
E4:26a If refrigerated vehicles are used. Refrigerated vehicle checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Check that all vehicles in the fleet comply. Only score an indicator as 'Y' if all vehicles in the fleet have the feature. Most countries will only have refrigerated vehicles at primary level, but some may use them at sub-national level.

select1.label: A. Are vehicles and refrigeration units in good mechanical condition
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Refrigerated vehicles may not be directly operated by the vaccine store. However, they are such a critical element in the supply chain that their specification and condition must be checked, even if they are operated by a parastatal, PPP or 3PL.

select1.label: B. Do the refrigeration units maintain a temperature of +2C to +8C? .
C. Are vehicles equipped with a self-sustained diesel refrigeration unit which can operate when the vehicle's engine is switched off?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: An independently powered refrigeration unit ensures that cooling is maintained when the main engine is switched off.

select1.label: D. Do refrigeration units have a standby electrical power system that can be plugged into a mains supply?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Standby electrical power is desirable where there are overnight stops. It is also desirable for smaller vehicles which do not have an independently powered refrigeration unit.

select1.label: E. If any refrigerated compartment is more than 6 metres long, does it have an air ducting system?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Needed to equalise temperatures in long vehicles.

select1.label: F. Are vehicles equipped with a thermometer which can be read in the driver's cab?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: This is a minimum requirement for any refrigerated vehicle.

select1.label: G. Are vehicles equipped with a temperature recorder which can produce hard copy output?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A temperature recorder is essential for larger vehicles and for long distance deliveries.

select1.label: H. Does the store have an electrical socket for the refrigerated vehicle's standby power system?
J. Is fuel available throughout the year

input.label: Notes:
E4:27a Transport container checklist:

select1.label: A. Answer ONLY if passive containers are kept at this facility. Do passive containers kept at this level comply with WHO specifications?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Passive containers include cold boxes, vaccine carriers and palletised or roll containers. Identify products by using the PQS or PIS catalogue.

select1.label: B. Answer ONLY if refrigerated vehicles are used. Are the disposable cartons or reusable crates used to transport vaccine fit for purpose.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: No standard set. Use judgement to assess quality. Most important is the way in which cartons or crates are packed and restrained.

input.label: E4:27a Notes:

group.label: E5 Maintenance of buildings, cold chain equipment and vehicles is satisfactory.

input.label: E5:01a Planned preventive maintenance checklist for buildings:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: This question is primarily about planned preventive maintenance (PPM). However, it is possible that the building is in good condition because it is being informally maintained. 01:C covers this option.

select1.label: A. Is there a written planned preventive maintenance (PPM) programme?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: An effective planned preventive maintenance programme for buildings should preferably cover several years into the future and should set target dates for routine maintenance such as re-decoration, electrical safety inspections, fire-extinguisher maintenance, etc. Some countries have annual plans and budgets.

select1.label: B. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: If the score to question A is 'N' then the score for Question B must also be 'N'. PPM activities should be monitored and recorded.

select1.label: C. Is there visual evidence that maintenance is taking place.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: If an effective maintenance programme is in place, the building should be in good condition. Indicators of poor building maintenance include broken light bulbs, leaks and damp stains, blocked drains, flaking paintwork, etc. See answers to E4:04a.

input.label: E5:01a Notes:
E5:02a If there is refrigeration equipment. Planned preventive maintenance checklist for refrigeration equipment:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: In this context, 'planned preventive maintenance' (PPM) is as set out in the cold chain equipment manufacturers' service manuals. Both the need for and the timing of PPM can be foreseen.

select1.label: A. Is there a written planned preventive maintenance (PPM) programme.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: An effective planned preventive maintenance programme for buildings should preferably cover several years into the future and should set target dates for routine maintenance such as re-decoration, electrical safety inspections, fire-extinguisher maintenance, etc. Some countries have annual plans and budgets.

select1.label: B. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: PPM should be recorded in a maintenance record book or worksheet.

select1.label: C. Is somebody assigned to carry out routine maintenance
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A permanent member of the facility staff must be formally assigned to carry out the tasks below. They should not be left to ancillary staff such as cleaners.

select1.label: D. Is there evidence that cold rooms/refrigerators/ freezers have recently been cleaned and defrosted?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check for excessive ice accumulation on evaporator units or the inside lining. Ice accumulation or condensation along the panel joints in cold rooms and freezer rooms is a sign that panel joints are leaking or poorly designed.

select1.label: E. If kerosene refrigerators are used, is there evidence that the wicks have been trimmed and chimneys cleaned?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Frequent trimming and replacement of wicks in kerosene refrigerators is absolutely essential. Chimneys also need to be cleaned regularly, especially if kerosene quality is poor.

select1.label: F. If solar refrigerators are used, are all solar panels clean and completely unshaded by buildings, trees and overhead cables?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Shading seriously degrades solar panel performance. Shading problems can increase over the years following the original installation as trees grow, new buildings are built and new overhead cables are erected. All solar panels should be cleaned from time to time to maintain efficiency. This is particularly important in dusty areas and in countries where there is snow.

select1.label: G. If battery powered solar refrigerators are used, is there evidence that the battery electrolyte has been checked recently?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Some flooded batteries are not sealed and require regular checking of electrolyte levels and topping up with battery acid.

input.label: E5:02a Notes:
E5:03a If vaccine transport is directly operated by this store. Transport maintenance and overhaul checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: This indicator only applies to government-operated vehicles - see E0:04a.A.

select1.label: A. Are vehicles serviced in accordance with the manufacturer's service manual?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: The service regime in the manufacturer's service manual must be followed. Vehicle service tasks include changing the engine oil, checking the condition of tyres, replacing the oil filter, replacing the air filter, etc.

select1.label: B. Is there documentary evidence that the service manual is being followed.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Documentary evidence' may be a service log book or a stamp in the service manual supplied with the vehicle.

select1.label: C. Is there a written planned preventive maintenance programme.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Vehicle preventive maintenance tasks include the dismantling or replacement of major components, such as clutch linings, engines, transmissions, etc. The timing may vary between similar vehicles, but the need can be foreseen.

select1.label: D. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed.

input.label: E5:03a Notes:
E5:04b If there are cold rooms and/or freezer rooms. Cold room and freezer room refrigeration unit maintenance checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: If the cold room or freezer room has standby refrigeration units, count the number of units.

input.label: A. How many refrigeration units are there?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Ignore equipment that has been officially decommissioned. Include any equipment that is temporarily switched off because it is not needed. Check that it operates.

input.label: B. How many were fully operational at the time of inspection?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Check if the unit Guidance Notes: has been out of operation for more than 7 days. If so, record this in the notes box.

input.label: C. Of the non-functional units, how many have been out of use for more than four weeks? Describe the reason(s) for this in the notes.
E5:04b Notes:
E5:05b If vaccine is stored at the facility AND there are refrigerators/freezers. Vaccine refrigerator and vaccine freezer maintenance checklist:
